@rabbah @psuter @markusthoemmes  @csantanapr thanks for helping.

By reusing a lot of pieces from the existing code-base I managed to create:

`make quick-start`
1. it builds the project and the docker container
   
   > NOTE: it reuses `gradlew distdocker`. 
2. then it starts all components using docker-compose and sets up the database reusing existing scripts
   
   >  I've also added an API Gateway based on NGINX and Openresty which for now it only does load-balancing but it can do much more. 
3. it then runs a sample `hello-world` function and prints the result
   
   > if all is good it prints
   > `{
   > "payload": "Hello, World!"
   > }`

To run the function again:

`make hello-world`

To stop the environment:

`make destroy`

This command stops all docker images, removing them, deleting the temporary folders, and also removing dangling docker volumes.

So now we have support for people who want to develop on docker `1.12+`.

@rabbah This PR is work in progress not ready.

I was already aware about replacing docker inspect for getting the info directly from config.json from under docker.

This PR is WIP, I wanted to investigate the option of having only for Mac Dev Environment  the ability of using `docker port`

This way we have an easier way for people to setup their local dev environment, by avoiding the special network route tweak, and the ability to use docker for mac instead of docker-machine if they like

I was planning to make it conditional, if Mac then, if not then use the current mode.

But then I was curious if using `docker port` we don't hit the performance problems of using `inspect` 

That's why I'm debating if I should make condition in code with if Mac, or maybe control it thru wiskprops.

By doing with wiskprops property we can control which method to use from the outside, and we can run the benchmark side by side more easier.

I think I would go in phases, solve one problem at a time and just solve it for Mac Dev, by detecting Mac.

Is this the appropriate issue in which to discuss the RAS design for the backend route management actions?  Since these are effectively OpenWhisk components, integrating the action logging with the OpenWhisk system logging would be important (Kibana access).  Also, we may need to consider some sort of "workflow" id, which is another correlator that wraps 1 or more actions - to handle the case when route management actions invoke other actions.
@mdeuser let's keep this issue focused on the API design, and move implementation stuff to separate issues.
This is great! I'll try to reproduce your steps in my environment and report back.

This is a know bug/feature and is working as intended. The underlying reason is that in openwhisk there isn't yet a mechanism to create more than one namespace per subject but in other deployments that provide IAM, it is possible to have more than one subject per namespace. In this case, activations require a way to disambiguate the namespace to hold the activation record which is not possible with one subject key mapping to more than one namespace.

As a result, all activations are stored in one namespace. The CLI ignores the namespace so that one can see all their activations. Before we fix the CLI, we need to resolve other blocking issues under #1107. So while we can fix the CLI, the list of activation in any namespace other that `_` will be empty.
See my comment in #1344. We can't merge this without introducing another "bug". This is blocked by the work on disambiguating activation namespaces (epic #1107).
I'll remove the changes that prevent the namespace from defaulting to "_" for activations. I would still like to get this PR merged as it contains changes to remove a lot of dead code.

> I'll remove the changes that prevent the namespace from defaulting to "_" for activations

how about: guard it with a feature toggle? we will need this, sooooon.
Is the route tweak even necessary for plain deployment of OpenWhisk. I was under the impression its only needed for the actionContainer tests? Everything else is handled inside the VM anyway?

On my first try, building and deployment seemed fine, but it then gets stuck doing:

```
waiting for the Whisk controller to come up
```

and the dots just keep adding up. Not sure whether this is related, but the container for the gateway seems to be listening to `:80` while the `curl` pinging seems to occur on `:8888`? Will look again later.

@psuter thanks for giving it a try. I'm wondering what docker version was used and if it's `>1.10`. The docker-compose makes ports for the components available on the localhost so that developers can test them directly. This assumes some ports would be available: `5984` (couchdb), `2181` (zk) , `9092` (kafka), `8400`,`8500`,`8600`, `8302` (consul), `8888`(controller), `8081` (invoker), `80` and `443` (gateway). 

curl pinging goes directly to the port of the component but to your point we could make it go through the gateway too.

I've actually updated my branch with the master and the controller logs show:

```
[ERROR] [??] [Config] required property defaultLimits.actions.invokes.concurrentInSystem still not set
```

It would be nice if such properties would set a default value and continue.

Making myself more familiar with invoker, you are correct when the invoker executes docker commands does them from it's container using the docker cli from the invoker container out to the host where docker engine is located.
For the run and init also you are correct going from invoker container to action container they seat on the same subnet so goes thru internal network

But I think I found some tests that call run and init from docker host, when tests runs in addition of actionContainer tests.
Take a look at [tests/src/whisk/core/container/test/ContainerPoolTests.scala](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/whisk/core/container/test/ContainerPoolTests.scala)

Is my assumption correct that when this tests run the run and init against the docker action happens from the machine running the test, not the invoker.

We've tried to avoid this by having default system properties defined in the ansible files.

Mostly a duplicate of #465

(comment below yanked from #1359)

After some experimentation, it became clear that the publish attribute for actions is not needed and, worse, can lead to confusion.

For example, create a package with --shared yes then create an action in that package also with --shared yes. Running wsk package get shows that the action has a publish value of false. However, running wsk action get on the actions shows the publish value set to true.

Additionally, running wsk action create --shared no to create an action inside a published package does not prevent others from invoking the action - that is, the publish value has no effect.

Lastly... creating an action outside of a shared package with --shared yes does not allow others to invoke that action.

tl;dr The publish attribute for actions (and [other non-package entities](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/465#issuecomment-220458240) as well) doesn't do anything, and should be removed.

This will affect the backend, CLI, and documentation.

I can provide a data point at least -- I've been preparing a demo using the 1.7 version over the week-end and have been putting together custom packages, binding them, creating triggers, rules, and actions etc. as well as testing them and running `wsk activation poll` for a few days -- no crashes and no problems so far.

Some additional notes for the record:
1. the publish attribute is a common property on all entities (includes rules, triggers, actions and packages)
2. only has an effect on packages (and the visibility of the package dictates the visibility of all assets in it)
3. there was some thinking to allow more fine grained sharing (private actions in a package) but since that's not implemented, the cleanest solution is to remove the property from the base type `WhiskEntity` and CLI commands.
@mdeuser, all the tests passed, but I ran all the tests for the CLI that was compiled with Go 1.7 over a month ago. Probably wouldn't hurt to run all the automated tests again.

@rabbah, I'm not sure that only building one CLI by default is the best option. The need to build only one binary is the result of wanting to speed up the local build process for developers. By building only one binary by default, we would complicate the production build process and testing environment. For instance, a flag to build/test all binaries in such environments would be needed even though we want all of the cross-platform binaries to always to be built in the mentioned environments. I think it makes more sense to require a developer that wants to speed up his, or her local build to set a necessary environment variable or pass a flag to the build.
Plus we could easily add a command to redo that would allow for only building the local binary.
Basically this is working now.  The builds (travis and PG2-318) are currently failing due to swift issues.

Its safer to return to the Swift Package Manager and remove the manual compilation.  We're vulnerable to secondary dependency changes when we deploy.  We can open a discussion around #1329 about how to avoid this.

IMHO the time-to-value is important for a person who's giving OpenWhisk a try. In my case it became a blocker as the build would timeout so I had to debug the problem and make some changes myself. In such a case the option suggested by @rabbah would be helpful.

That last bit from @jthomas about annotating an action really needs to be better documented and perhaps given first class syntax.

 `-a feed true` -- adds a feed annotation to the action and is required to register it as a feed provider

pg1/595 running.

Team meeting decision from Oct 4:
- we will go forward with user namespaces
- we will not mount containers read-only
- we will limit storage using overlay2 + xfs using docker 1.13 (modulo stemcell being able to mount root fs as xfs)
- if xfs not possible, pursue other solutions like io-limits or watchdogs until ext4 quota arrives

pr #1364 updates the limits although these limits are specific to bluemix and not local development.
@rr thanks, missed that one
Fixes #1365

As noted in the issue, the limits documented here are specific to bluemix and not local development. The values for openwhisk come from here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all#L10 and here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/environments/local/group_vars/all#L20 for ubuntu (similar for mac).
So it means this PR is invalid on this repo then
